newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Airlines profits said hit by soaring fuel costs.
newsitem.headline: Airlines profits said hit by soaring fuel costs.

text.p: World airlines appear headed for their second year in a row of record profits but soaring fuel costs are slicing into their overall revenues, the head of the industry's global body IATA reported on Monday.

And IATA Director-General Pierre Jeanniot warned executives from over 250 member companies that a rush by carriers into hasty alliances to capture a bigger chunk of the booming market could bring more problems than successes.

"This year should deliver another record profit....With interest charges slightly decreased, we would be looking at a net result of $5.5 billion," Jeanniot told the annual general meeting of IATA, the International Air Transport Association.

But that figure would be well down on the $6 billion he forecast in April this year before jet diesel price rises began seriously hitting the airlines, 11 per cent of whose costs are accounted for by fuel.

IATA airlines, who include highly profitable companies as well as chronic lossmakers, are fighting to fill the $15.6 billion hole left in their coffers by the recession of the early 1990s and the Gulf Crisis of 1990-91.

In 1994 and 1995, as passengers returned to the 98 per cent of all international routes covered by IATA companies, overall revenues began to climb and in 1995 reached $5.2 billion -- partly due to the industry surge in Asia and the Pacific.

In his speech prepared for delivery on Monday, Jeanniot said that last year's all-time record -- representing four per cent of total revenues of $128 billion -- was underpinned by a total traffic growth, passenger and cargo, of 8.2 per cent.

"Airlines have downsized, outsourced, concentrated on core business....We could be reaching a point of diminishing returns in our ability to deliver further significant reductions in unit cost," the former Air Canada chief declared.

"And their are various things that can divert us from our prifitable flight path, such as infrastructure charges, which are outside our control," he said, referring to mounting levies by airports and by governments for air traffic control services.

But Jeanniot signalled a key concern was fuel, for which airlines paid an average world-wide price last year of 65.2 U.S. cents a gallon but soared to 77.5 cents in September after the United States fired 27 Cruise missiles against Iraq.

Tension in the Gulf, source of much of the world's oil, generally sparks fuel price rises. At the weekend, a U.S. plane in the region fired another missile at an Iraqi target, but neither side appears to want to build up the incident.

Many European airlines have already announced they are putting up prices because of fuel costs, and IATA has called an emergency meeting in Geneva next week to discuss a concerted response by its members.
